abstract.p: His thoughts on the lack of horns in domesticated cattle.

div.p: I have not had time, during several years, to attend to the very interesting subject of domesticated animals. No one can give any explanation—although, no doubt, there must be a cause of the loss of horns—any more than of the loss of hair, both losses strongly tending to be inherited. It is, I think, probable that the loss of horns has occurred often since cattle were domesticated, though I can call to mind only a case in Paraguay, about a century ago. Is there not a sub-breed of the so-called Wild Park cattle which is hornless?

div.note: This extract was published under the pen name Sigma, and prefaced with the words, ‘I have been privileged with the perusal of an unpublished letter from Mr. Darwin, dated Jan. 28, 1882—three months before his death—in which, responding to an enquiry for information as to the probable cause of the loss of horns, this distinguished naturalist wrote:’. Sigma was the pen name of Samuel Newington.
Sinclair had asked CD about his views on hornless cattle; see Correspondence vol. 30, letter from James Sinclair, 21 January 1882.
Probably a reference to the wild cattle of Chillingham Park in Northumberland (see Correspondence vol. 30, Supplement, letter to C. A. Bennet, [before 3 January 1865]).
